etymologies: late 16th century: probably dialect; perhaps related to obsolete snike ‘to creep’

notes.text: The traditional standard past form of sneak is sneaked (she sneaked around the corner). An alternative past form, snuck (she snuck past me), arose in the US in the 19th century. Until very recently, snuck was confined to US dialect use and was regarded as nonstandard. However, in the last few decades, its use has spread in the US, where it is now regarded as a standard alternative to sneaked in all but the most formal contexts. In the Oxford English Corpus, there are now more US citations for snuck than there are for sneaked, and there is evidence of snuck gaining ground in British English as well

definitions: move or go in a furtive or stealthy manner

examples.text: I sneaked out by the back exit

shortDefinitions: move or go in furtive or stealthy manner

definitions: convey (someone or something) in a furtive or stealthy way
shortDefinitions: convey person or thing in such way

definitions: do or obtain (something) in a stealthy or furtive way

examples.text: she sneaked a glance at her watch

shortDefinitions: do or obtain something in stealthy or furtive way

definitions: creep up on (someone) without being detected

examples.text: he sneaks up on us slyly

shortDefinitions: creep up on someone without being detected

Until very recently, snuck was confined to US dialect use and was regarded as nonstandard. examples.text: he was branded a prying sneak for eavesdropping on intimate conversation

definitions: acting or done surreptitiously, unofficially, or without warning
shortDefinitions: acting or done surreptitiously, unofficially, or without warning
